Award.AwardTitle: Visualizing Charge Carrier Dynamics in Semiconductor Nanowires Using Femtosecond Pump-Probe Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor John M. Papanikolas of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to use time-resolved microscopy to image the motion of charges in one-dimensional semiconductor nanowires on ultrafast time scales. The derived information is fundamentally important and critical to understanding many aspects of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Variation in behavior from structure-to-structure (and even between different locations within the same structure) is a hallmark of complexity and poses a major challenge to those wishing to use nanoscale materials in device applications. In addition to providing new insights into charge behavior in complex nanostructures, the project will promote the development of future scientists. Graduate, undergraduate, and high school students will participate in this research. They will develop the technologically complex instrumentation, apply those instruments to methods for the study of single nanostructures, and take part in the communication of their results at national meetings.

Professor Papanikolas and his students will utilize a new pump-probe microscopy technique that excites nanowires in one spatial location and probes them in another, on time scales ranging from femtoseconds to nanoseconds. They will use this spatially-separated pump-probe microscope to visualize the motion of charges (electrons and holes) in nanowires with complex shapes and compositional variations, including Si nanowires encoded with axial constrictions, as well as bent and kinked nanowires. They will also develop low-temperature capabilities that will enable them to observe ballistic transport in Si/Ge core-shell nanowires. This project aims to enhance basic understanding of how structural features influence the flow of charges through individual nanowires, and thereby provide valuable information that could be used in future nano-device applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is intense interest in semiconductor nanostructures for use in a wide variety of nanotechnologies, including solar energy conversion, nanoelectronics and photonics. This project advanced an optical microscope for studying the charge-carrier dynamics of individual nanostructures with combined spatial and temporal resolution.  A key feature of the microscope is its ability to perform detailed measurements at distinct locations within a single structure, enabling a correlation of dynamical phenomena with structural features such as edges and bending deformations.  The microscope is also capable of exciting a structure in one location and probe it in another, enabling the direct visualization of electron motion, thermal diffusion and phonon propagation. This capability provides a unique view of transport phenomena that is difficult (or impossible) to obtain using conventional experimental methods. The microscope was used to image the carrier recombination dynamics in undoped Si nanowires (NWs), providing a direct view of the surface properties of NWs. Our experiments show that the surface defect densities can vary by almost two orders of magnitude across an ensemble of NWs grown at the same time.  This result has important implications for using nanowires in device applications. We also used this microscope to image the transport of thermal energy (i.e. heat) in suspended NWs, demonstrating that the method could be used to measure thermal conductivities in nanostructures. Pump-probe microscopy experiments performed on the suspended Ge NWs show acoustical phonons that correspond to a combination of a radial breathing mode of the NW and a longitudinally propagating shock wave created by the optical excitation. Subsequent experiments on layered semiconductor (e.g. MoS2) nanoflakes exhibit dramatic spatial variation in the carrier recombination dynamics, with the edges of the flakes exhibiting faster relaxation than the center.  This result could provide valuable insight into the catalytic function of these materials in solar fuels applications.  The project also contributed to the training of future scientists. Graduate student training was an important aspect of the research effort and a number of graduate students, undergraduates and high school students participated in this work. They developed technologically sophisticated instrumentation and large-scale computer models, and have applied them to the study of novel materials. They have aided with data collection and analysis, co-authored publications, and have presented their findings at national meetings.
